factoid: The door leads into a back anteroom.
The old man, who is a servant of the princesses, sat in a corner knitting a stocking.
Pierre had never been in this part of the house.
Pierre did not know of the existence of these rooms.
Anna Mikháylovna addressed a maid who was hurrying past with a decanter on a tray as “my dear” and “my sweet.”
Anna Mikháylovna asked about the princess’ health.
Anna Mikháylovna led Pierre along a stone passage.
The first door on the left leads into the princesses’ apartments.
The maid with the decanter had not closed the door.
Pierre and Anna Mikháylovna instinctively glanced into the room.
Prince Vasíli and the eldest princess were sitting close together talking.
Prince Vasíli drew back with obvious impatience.
The eldest princess jumped up and slammed the door with all her might with a gesture of desperation.
The action was unlike the eldest princess's usual composure.
The fear on Prince Vasíli’s face was out of keeping with his dignity.
Pierre stopped and glanced inquiringly over his spectacles at Anna Mikháylovna.
Anna Mikháylovna evinced no surprise.
Anna Mikháylovna smiled faintly and sighed.
Anna Mikháylovna implied that this was no more than she had expected.
Anna Mikháylovna told Pierre to be a man.
Anna Mikháylovna said she will look after Pierre's interests.
Anna Mikháylovna went faster along the passage.
Pierre could not understand what was happening.
Pierre could not understand what “watching over his interests” meant.
Pierre decided that all these things had to be.
They entered a large, dimly lit room adjoining the count’s reception room.
The room was a sumptuous but cold apartment known to Pierre only from the front approach.
An empty bath stood in the room.
Water had been spilled on the carpet.
A deacon with a censer met them.
A servant passed out on tiptoe without heeding them.
They entered the reception room familiar to Pierre.
The reception room had two Italian windows opening into the conservatory.
The conservatory had a large bust and a full-length portrait of Catherine the Great.
The same people were sitting in almost the same positions as before, whispering to one another.
All became silent and turned to look at Anna Mikháylovna.
All became silent and turned to look at Pierre.
Pierre was hanging his head and meekly followed Anna Mikháylovna.
Anna Mikháylovna's face expressed that the decisive moment had arrived.
Anna Mikháylovna entered the room more boldly than that afternoon, keeping Pierre close beside her.
Anna Mikháylovna felt that by bringing the person the dying man wished to see, her own admission was assured.
Anna Mikháylovna cast a rapid glance at all those in the room.
Anna Mikháylovna noticed the count’s confessor there.
Anna Mikháylovna glided up to the count’s confessor.
Anna Mikháylovna respectfully received a blessing from one priest.
Anna Mikháylovna respectfully received a blessing from another priest.
Anna Mikháylovna told a priest that God be thanked that he is in time.
Anna Mikháylovna said that all relatives have been in such anxiety.
Anna Mikháylovna said that this young man is the count’s son.
Anna Mikháylovna said “What a terrible moment!”.
Anna Mikháylovna went up to the doctor.
Anna Mikháylovna addressed the doctor as “Dear doctor.”
Anna Mikháylovna said that this young man is the count’s son.
Anna Mikháylovna asked the doctor if there is any hope.
The doctor cast a rapid glance upwards.
The doctor silently shrugged his shoulders.
Anna Mikháylovna raised her shoulders and eyes, almost closing the eyes.
Anna Mikháylovna sighed.
Anna Mikháylovna moved away from the doctor to Pierre.
Anna Mikháylovna said to Pierre “Trust in His mercy!”.
Anna Mikháylovna pointed out a small sofa for Pierre to sit and wait for her.
Anna Mikháylovna went silently toward the door.
The door creaked very slightly as Anna Mikháylovna disappeared behind it.
